# Task

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.



# Data

timezone_bumper(DateTime(2023, 4, 10, 12, 0),3)

You can use the following Julia code to solve this problem:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumber(dt::DateTime, bump = 3)
    if typeof(dt) != DateTime
        throw(ArgumentError("Only DateTime type is allowed."))
    end
    
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end
```
Here `Hour` is a unit of time in Julia's Dates module. This function will bump the provided datetime by the specified number of hours, defaults to 3 hours if no value is passed in. If a date type is passed instead of DateTime it throws an ArgumentError stating "Only DateTime type is allowed".
